content: I'm attending a breakfast meeting with my congressman Monday (3/30) morning. I'm looking for talking points. What veteran's issues need to be brought up? One issue is the aborted attempt to abandon disabled veterans to the private, for profit, insurances companies. Though not a veteran's issue I intend to mention the "Rangle Rule." Since Rep. Charles Rangle (D NY) did NOT have to pay any fines or penalties for under-reporting income, no American tax payer should be required to pay such fines or penalties. Add your concerns to the discussion. I'll compile some talking points Sunday night. Bill

content: I'd like to know if this adminstration is going to follow through on the proposed increase in VA dis-ability. Bush asked for and was recieved a external investigation and it was recommended that the present VA pay tables stood today as they did back in the late 50s and to bring the dis-abled vets drawing VA dis-ability FWD, an increase of 25% was recommended. That was the last I heard anything about the end report delivered to the WH.

title: What veteran's issues need to be brought to the attention of congress?

content: Equality for federal and state contracts by certified veterans businesses and active reserve personnel. Commensurate status with women and minorities in competition for contracts. Why? Reservists and mustering out troops need to build "good will" again in their communities since they have been away for such a long period of time...and many of their jobs have been eliminated or others were hired to take their place in spite of the federal laws that go unenforced to give them their jobs back. Seamless health care from deployment, DROS, to mustering out back into civilian life. VA provides service-connected medical care and if over 50% service connected, total health care for disabled veterans. Why? Once over 50% your ability to earn a living is severely impacted.
reply: Equality for federal and state contracts by certified veterans businesses and active reserve personnel. Commensurate status with women and minorities in competition for contracts. Why? content: I found it interesting when I came back from Vietnam the Vietnam refugees were qualifying for low interest rate business loans... and I could not?? That was a real kick in the azz.

title: What veteran's issues need to be brought to the attention of congress?

content: Thanks for this topic. Slow VA claims processing is the major problem, followed by VA Healthcare demands not being met due to lack of funding. People returning from OEF and OIF who are disabled and released from active duty back into the community must wait many months for the VA Adjudication process to be completed. PTSD, TBI, and acquired illnesses claims have wounds not visible to the eye and often prevent the returnee from resuming a living. Then the often long wait for the process to be completed. We know the fast track is in place, but it still takes many months in most cases to get PTSD and acquired illness cases resolved. In a few months of low, or no income the veteran often loses what they had worked to achieve. Mental Healthcare is limited far more than an acceptable level. Budget planning for VA should consider the Veteran Service Organizations (VSO) recommended budget which is submitted annually. The VSO's put much effort into determination of needs of the veteran. Here is a link to important veteran issues, which was started Wednesday 26 November 2003 and has 231 pages with 3,458 posts and 129,413 views. It contains veteran issues and discussion. http://forums.military.com/eve/forums/a/tpc/f/8280047191001/m/8311979586 I will cast no stones. Proud member of the RD-DV! Military.com is the original home of the Derelict Veterans Group, RD-DV, established December 31, 2008

title: What veteran's issues need to be brought to the attention of congress?

content: Just to support the above post I made. On the first page of the topic I linked, you will find the following post: Posted Wed 26 November 2003 which was posted by me from the VA Hotline. This was 5 1/2 years ago and still is a major problem. The following is a brief description of some of the key steps that VA has taken to prepare for veterans from Operations Iraqi Freedom (OIF) and Enduring Freedom (OEF) in the 7 months since the start of Operation Iraqi Freedom (March 19th, 2003). Immediate Health Care Needs for Combat Veterans: In response to immediate health concerns for OIF and OEF veterans, on March 26 and 27, 2003, VA developed a program called “Caring for the War Wounded,” which was broadcast over the VA Knowledge Network satellite broadcast system. Provided timely and relevant information about the anticipated health care needs of veterans of the current conflict in Iraq. Included VA experts on treatments for traumatic injuries; chemical warfare agent health effects; infectious diseases; radiological health effects; and post-deployment readjustment health concerns. Made a new Veterans Health Initiative (VHI) independent study guide, called “Caring for the War Wounded,” which is available to all VA health care providers online at vaww.va.gov/VHI/ and on the Internet at http://www.appc1.va.gov/vhi/. New Clinical Guidelines for Combat Veteran Health Care: In collaboration with DoD, VA developed two Clinical Practice Guidelines on combat veteran health issues, including one general guideline to post-deployment health, and a second dealing with unexplained pain and fatigue. Give our providers the best medical evidence for diagnoses and treatment. Highly recommended for the evaluation and care of all returning combat veterans, including OIF and OEF veterans. Available on line at www.va.gov/environagents, under the heading, “Environmental Health Clinicians.” New Specialized Combat Veteran Health Care Program: In 2001, VA established two new War Related Illness and Injury Study Centers, or “WRIISCs” as they have become to be known, at the Washington, DC, and East Orange, NJ VAMCs. Today providing specialized health care for combat veterans from all deployments who experience difficult to diagnose but disabling illnesses. Concerns about unexplained illness are seen after all deployments including OIF, but we are building on our understand of these illnesses. More information available online at www.va.gov/environagents under the heading “ WRIISC Referral Eligibility Information.” Expanded Education on Combat Health Care for VA Providers: In addition to the programs already described, VA has developed a Veterans Health Initiative (VHI) Independent Study Guide called “A Guide to Gulf War Veterans Health.” Originally on health care for combat veterans from the 1991 Gulf War, this product is also very relevant for OIF and OEF combat veterans because most of the hazardous exposures are the same. Written for both clinicians, and for veterans and their families. Available in print, on a CD ROM. Outreach to Combat Veterans: VA has many new products to offer combat veterans and their families. In collaboration with DoD, VA published and distributed one million copies of a new short brochure called “A Summary of VA Benefits for National Guard and Reservists Personnel.” which summarizes health care and other benefits available to this special population of combat veterans upon their return to civilian life. It is also available online at www.va.gov/environagents near the bottom of the page. Another brochure produced called “Health Care and Assistance for U.S. Veterans of Operation Iraqi Freedom,” on basic health issues for that deployment. Improvements in Health Care Eligibility: VA has promoted new eligibility rules that provide reservists and active duty personnel who served in a designated combat zone such as Iraq or Afghanistan with 2 years of free health care from VA. Streamlines access to health care for recently separated combat veterans. Summarized in the brochure “Special VA Healthcare Eligibility for Combat Veterans. Special DU program: OIF veterans concerned about possible exposure to depleted uranium can be evaluated using a special DU exposure protocol that VA began after the 1991 Gulf War. Combat Veteran Health Status Surveillance: Today we can monitor the overall health status of combat veterans remarkably well using VA’s electronic inpatient and outpatient medical records. This surveillance summarizes every single visit by a combat veteran including all medical diagnoses. VA’s Gulf War registry remains open to all OIF veterans. Finally, we are developing a new Clinical Reminder (part of VA’s computerized reminder system) to assist VA primary care clinicians in providing timely and appropriate care to new combat veterans. I will cast no stones. Proud member of the RD-DV! Military.com is the original home of the Derelict Veterans Group, RD-DV, established December 31, 2008

title: What veteran's issues need to be brought to the attention of congress?

content: Bill, I will admit, I have done zero research on this mostly because; a) this just happened in the past week b) my concern is for my neighbor, not me My neighbor is a Vietnam Vet suffering from exposure to Agent Orange. He must use a wheelchair to get around. The other night around 1:00 a.m., his wife had to take him to the VA in Manchester, NH, about 20 miles away to check him in for a medical emergency....heart failure. I asked her, "Why didn't an ambulance respond?" She told me that she had to take him to the VA in Manchester to check him in, then they send him to the correct hospital. If the local ambulance crew came, they would have taken him to the nearest hospital which is in Exeter, NH and not a VA hospital. To me, if it's something as critical as possible heart failure, I would think he should go to the nearest ER and the VA should handle it but I guess that's not how things work with them. Your choice if you think this should be mentioned. I just thought I'd bring it up. Don By the way...he came back home after a few days in the hospital. His wife feels they sent him home too soon.

content: Bill, Add to your list Concurrent Receipt. Yes it is supposed to be phased in for those at 50% or more now. But how much longer till it is done for everyone? Another decade? And how do you know when you might receive it? There is no notification, that I know of yet.

content: "What veteran's issues need to be brought to the attention of congress?" A couple things come to mind. We could use a little more equanimity in Tricare benefits for Guard and Reserve people. Right now they have to wait quite awhile to get coverage. The other thing is making the coverage more competitive with real world insurance and people's needs. There are so many meds that aren't covered in either Tricare or via the VA. They're both very slow in adopting the newest and best meds. And... making tricare primary.

title: What veteran's issues need to be brought to the attention of congress?

content: Since my time will be limited here are the issues I will present: quote: The length of time the VA takes to adjudicate injuries such as Post Traumatic Stress Disorder, Traumatic Brain Injury, or acquired illnesses; War injuries without physical manifestations; Is so long that the unfortunate wounded veterans stand to lose all they have worked their whole lives for. This is a disservice to those who were asked to put it all on the line for our nation. The compensation schedules for our disabled warriors were established in the late 1950’s and haven’t been changed since. Before giving welfare to terrorists released from GITMO the veterans who answered the nations call deserve a raise. An investigation during the Bush administration recommended 25% but nothing has become of it. Also consider when a veteran is 50% disabled or more their ability to earn a living is seriously affected. Certified Veteran Owned Businesses should be given the same consideration as woman owned businesses or minority owned businesses when competing for contracts. With a greater reliance on reserve and guard units for deployments those who are sacrificing for the good of our nation should never be put at the back of the line.

content: Mission Accomplished! I presented the three points to the congressman this morning. He asked me to be a member of his Veteran's Advisory Committee. I guess if you speak up you gotta' be ready to back it up with some involvement. Some interesting factoids: Obama's 2010 budget will accumulate more debt then was accumulated by all 43 presidents that preceded him. 250,000 new bureaucrats will be needed to spend all the money allocated in Obama’s budget. Obama forced the CEO of GM to resign and the rumor is that Barney Frank will be appointed to re-organize GM.

content: If there is a message it is: You gotta’ put yourself out there and be willing to get involved. BTW, as I mentioned previously, I have nothing to gain by any of these issues. My 4 years active were injury free and relatively comfortable. It's survivor’s guilt; 58,000 of my peers were killed in Vietnam and over 300,000 were injured while I was in no danger. I can only wonder how I would have conducted myself if I had been sent to Vietnam. I can only wonder how I would have conducted myself if I were young enough and healthy enough to be deployed to Iraq or Afghanistan.

BTW, as I mentioned previously, I have nothing to gain by any of these issues. My 4 years active were injury free and relatively comfortable. It's survivor’s guilt; 58,000 of my peers were killed in Vietnam and over 300,000 were injured while I was in no danger. I can only wonder how I would have conducted myself if I had been sent to Vietnam. I can only wonder how I would have conducted myself if I were young enough and healthy enough to be deployed to Iraq or Afghanistan. You are a special advocate I will cast no stones. Proud member of the RD-DV! Military.com is the original home of the Derelict Veterans Group, RD-DV, established December 31, 2008

title: What veteran's issues need to be brought to the attention of congress?

content: quote: Originally posted by DragonRider01: quote: Originally posted by SignalSgtWilliams: quote: Originally posted by DragonRider01: Bill, Add to your list Concurrent Receipt. Yes it is supposed to be phased in for those at 50% or more now. But how much longer till it is done for everyone? Another decade? And how do you know when you might receive it? There is no notification, that I know of yet. You might want to head over to the Veteran's Issue boards. They have all the update on this matter. Yeah, I have been looking over there. Unfortunately I have not found anything specific - just similar questions. Thanks though. Each branch is on their own track and it is difficult to get answers. Call DFAS and ask your status. We try to cover these issues on my Sound Off Discussion Board. Please take a look, there are two pages of veteran/retiree issues carefully monitored. http://forums.military.com/eve/forums/a/frm/f/8280047191001 I will cast no stones. Proud member of the RD-DV! Military.com is the original home of the Derelict Veterans Group, RD-DV, established December 31, 2008
